page.title: 15Sywell Airport.
page.content: The airport in Sywell was built in 1928. The airport was used during the Second World War to teach R.A.F. pilots to fly and a number of Wellington Bombers were built there. Many famous people have visited Sywell including Her Royal Highness The Queen in July, 1965. The B.B.C. used the airport to film the story of Amy Johnson. Today, the airport has three grass runways, covering approximately 360 acres. They are 909 metres, 700 metres and 528 metres long. A grass crop is grown every year in the triangle in the middle of the runways. An average of 660 aircraft use the airport each month. In addition to this, there is an active school of flying which use the airport for local flights. Many helicopters use the airport. The airport is bordered by farmland and by the local Motel.
